title: maxbootR-intro
text: maxbootR package provides fast user-friendly tools block-based bootstrapping extreme value statistics. supports disjoint, sliding, circular block schemes, powered C++ backends via Rcpp speed scalability. vignette, demonstrate typical workflows : Estimating extreme quantiles log-return data finance Estimating 100-year return levels temperature data climatology case studies include core steps: Extracting different types block maxima Applying maxbootR() bootstrap estimation function

what: Case Study 1: Log Returns from the S&P 500 Index
title: maxbootR-intro
text: begin inspecting dataset logret_data, included package. contains daily negative log returns S&P 500 stock market index 1995 2024. interested estimating 0.99 quantile maximum yearly negative log returns. diving , let’s visualize raw data check completeness anomalies.  data appears complete contains missing values.

title: maxbootR-intro
text: set block size 250 (approx. number trading days per year) compute disjoint sliding block maxima.
code: bsize <- 250 bm_db <- blockmax(logret_data$neg_log_ret, block_size = bsize, type = "db") #> Warning in blockmax(logret_data$neg_log_ret, block_size = bsize, type = "db"): #> The block size does not divide the sample size. The final block is handled #> dynamically. bm_sb <- blockmax(logret_data$neg_log_ret, block_size = bsize, type = "sb") #> Warning in blockmax(logret_data$neg_log_ret, block_size = bsize, type = "sb"): #> The block size does not divide the sample size. The final block is handled #> dynamically.  # Time vector per block type day_db <- logret_data$day[seq(1, length(bm_db) * bsize, by = bsize)] day_sb <- logret_data$day[1:length(bm_sb)]  # Combine into tidy tibble df_db <- tibble(day = day_db, value = bm_db, method = "Disjoint Blocks") df_sb <- tibble(day = day_sb, value = bm_sb, method = "Sliding Blocks") df_all <- bind_rows(df_db, df_sb)  # Plot ggplot(df_all, aes(x = day, y = value)) +   geom_line(color = "steelblue") +   facet_wrap(~ method, nrow = 1) +   labs(title = "Block Maxima of Negative Log-Returns",        x = "Date", y = "Block Maximum")

title: maxbootR-intro
text: now bootstrap 0.99 quantile yearly maxima using disjoint sliding block methods. understand expected quantile behavior, also bootstrap shape parameter fitted Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution. estimates reveal heavy tails: cases, median shape parameter > 0.3, indicating large extremes expected – motivates trimming next step.
code: bst.bm_db_gev <- maxbootr(   xx = logret_data$neg_log_ret, est = "gev", block_size = 250,    B = 1000, type = "db" )  #> Warning in blockmax(xx, block_size, type = "db"): The block size does not #> divide the sample size. The final block is handled dynamically. summary(bst.bm_db_gev[, 3]) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #> -0.6065  0.2234  0.3210  0.3411  0.4291  1.1869  bst.bm_sb_gev <- maxbootr(   xx = logret_data$neg_log_ret, est = "gev", block_size = 250,    B = 1000, type = "sb" ) #> Warning in blockmax(xx, block_size, type = "cb"): The block size does not #> divide the sample size. The final block is handled dynamically. summary(bst.bm_sb_gev[, 3]) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #> -0.1518  0.2294  0.3149  0.3283  0.4055  1.0318

title: maxbootR-intro
text: distribution right-skewed contains high values due large shape parameters. truncate bootstrap replicates 98% quantile visualize compare main mass distribution.
code: bst.bm_db_q <- maxbootr(   xx = logret_data$neg_log_ret, est = "quantile", block_size = 250,    B = 1000, type = "db", p = 0.99 )  #> Warning in blockmax(xx, block_size, type = "db"): The block size does not #> divide the sample size. The final block is handled dynamically. summary(bst.bm_db_q) #>        V1          #>  Min.   :0.04382   #>  1st Qu.:0.14031   #>  Median :0.17633   #>  Mean   :0.21232   #>  3rd Qu.:0.22586   #>  Max.   :1.87622  bst.bm_sb_q <- maxbootr(   xx = logret_data$neg_log_ret, est = "quantile", block_size = 250,    B = 1000, type = "sb", p = 0.99 ) #> Warning in blockmax(xx, block_size, type = "cb"): The block size does not #> divide the sample size. The final block is handled dynamically. summary(bst.bm_sb_q) #>        V1          #>  Min.   :0.07626   #>  1st Qu.:0.14480   #>  Median :0.17611   #>  Mean   :0.19415   #>  3rd Qu.:0.21240   #>  Max.   :1.17018 # Trim upper 2% of bootstrap replicates bst.bm_db_q_trimmed <- bst.bm_db_q[bst.bm_db_q < quantile(bst.bm_db_q, 0.98)] bst.bm_sb_q_trimmed <- bst.bm_sb_q[bst.bm_sb_q < quantile(bst.bm_sb_q, 0.98)]  # Combine for plotting df_q <- tibble(   value = c(bst.bm_db_q_trimmed, bst.bm_sb_q_trimmed),   method = c(rep("Disjoint Blocks", length(bst.bm_db_q_trimmed)),              rep("Sliding Blocks", length(bst.bm_sb_q_trimmed))) )  # Histogram plot ggplot(df_q, aes(x = value)) +   geom_histogram(fill = "steelblue", color = "white", bins = 30) +   facet_wrap(~ method, nrow = 1) +   labs(     title = "Bootstrap Estimates of Extreme Quantile",     x = "Estimated Quantile",     y = "Count"   )

title: maxbootR-intro
text: variance ratio around 0.43, indicating sliding block approach results considerably lower estimation uncertainty.
code: # Variance ratio var(bst.bm_sb_q_trimmed) / var(bst.bm_db_q_trimmed) #> [1] 0.4292346

what: Visualizing the Bootstrap Quantile on the Time Series
title: maxbootR-intro
text: now visualize original time series overlay median bootstrapped 0.99 quantile (sliding blocks).  large distance observed returns 99% quantile reflects rather small observation window 30 years, one estimates 99% quantile.
code: q99 <- quantile(bst.bm_sb_q_trimmed, 0.5)  ggplot(logret_data, aes(x = day, y = neg_log_ret)) +   geom_line(color = "steelblue") +   geom_hline(yintercept = q99, color = "red", linetype = "dashed") +   labs(     title = "Daily Negative Log-Returns with Extreme Quantile",     x = "Date",     y = "Negative Log-Return"   )

what: Case Study 2: Maximal Temperature at Hohenpeißenberg
title: maxbootR-intro
text: second case study, follow similar routine analogous steps. dataset contains daily temperature measurements Hohenpeißenberg weather station Germany, covering years 1878 2023 (145 years). interested estimating 100-year return level daily temperatures. data highly non-stationary, can seen following time series plots:  mitigate non-stationarity, extract summer months. little impact disjoint block bootstrap, significantly improves performance sliding block method.

title: maxbootR-intro
text: Since restrict summer months, use block size 92 days (approximate length summer).
code: bsize <- 92 bm_db_temp <- blockmax(temp_data_cl$temp, block_size = bsize, type = "db") bm_sb_temp <- blockmax(temp_data_cl$temp, block_size = bsize, type = "sb")  # Create time vectors for plotting day_db_temp <- temp_data_cl$day[seq(1, length(bm_db_temp) * bsize, by = bsize)] day_sb_temp <- temp_data_cl$day[1:length(bm_sb_temp)]  # Create tidy tibble for plotting df_db_temp <- tibble(day = day_db_temp, value = bm_db_temp, method = "Disjoint Blocks") df_sb_temp <- tibble(day = day_sb_temp, value = bm_sb_temp, method = "Sliding Blocks") df_all_temp <- bind_rows(df_db_temp, df_sb_temp)  # Plot block maxima ggplot(df_all_temp, aes(x = day, y = value)) +   geom_line(color = "steelblue") +   facet_wrap(~ method, nrow = 1) +   labs(title = "Block Maxima of Summer Temperatures",        x = "Date", y = "Block Maximum")

title: maxbootR-intro
text: proceed directly estimating 100-year return level via bootstrapping. visualize resulting bootstrap distributions using histograms.
code: bst.bm_db_temp_q <- maxbootr(   xx = temp_data_cl$temp, est = "rl", block_size = bsize,    B = 1000, type = "db", annuity = 100 ) summary(bst.bm_db_temp_q) #>        V1        #>  Min.   :32.09   #>  1st Qu.:33.05   #>  Median :33.32   #>  Mean   :33.32   #>  3rd Qu.:33.59   #>  Max.   :34.76  bst.bm_sb_temp_q <- maxbootr(   xx = temp_data_cl$temp, est = "rl", block_size = bsize,    B = 1000, type = "sb", annuity = 100 ) summary(bst.bm_sb_temp_q) #>        V1        #>  Min.   :31.63   #>  1st Qu.:32.84   #>  Median :33.09   #>  Mean   :33.08   #>  3rd Qu.:33.33   #>  Max.   :34.31 # Combine for plotting df_q_temp <- tibble(   value = c(bst.bm_db_temp_q, bst.bm_sb_temp_q),   method = c(rep("Disjoint Blocks", length(bst.bm_db_temp_q)),              rep("Sliding Blocks", length(bst.bm_sb_temp_q))) )  # Histogram plot ggplot(df_q_temp, aes(x = value)) +   geom_histogram(fill = "steelblue", color = "white", bins = 30) +   facet_wrap(~ method, nrow = 1) +   labs(     title = "Bootstrap Estimates of 100-Year Return Level",     x = "Estimated Return Level",     y = "Count"   )

title: maxbootR-intro
text: variance ratio approximately 0.85, indicating sliding block bootstrap reduces estimation variance compared disjoint approach.
code: # Compute and display variance ratio var(bst.bm_sb_temp_q) / var(bst.bm_db_temp_q) #>           [,1] #> [1,] 0.8494002

what: Visualizing the Return Level on the Time Series
title: maxbootR-intro
text: now overlay median return level estimate onto original (summer-) time series.
code: rl <- quantile(bst.bm_sb_temp_q, 0.5)  ggplot(temp_data, aes(x = day, y = temp)) +   geom_line(color = "steelblue") +   geom_hline(yintercept = rl, color = "red", linetype = "dashed") +   labs(     title = "All Temperatures with Estimated 100-Year Return Level",     x = "Date",     y = "Daily Max Temperature"   )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Torben Staud. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Staud T (2025). maxbootR: Efficient Bootstrap Methods Block Maxima. R package version 0.0.1, https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.05529, https://github.com/torbenstaud/maxbootR, https://torbenstaud.github.io/maxbootR/, https://torbenstaud.github.io/maxbootR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {maxbootR: Efficient Bootstrap Methods for Block Maxima},   author = {Torben Staud},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.1, https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.05529, https://github.com/torbenstaud/maxbootR, https://torbenstaud.github.io/maxbootR/},   url = {https://torbenstaud.github.io/maxbootR}, }

title: maxbootR
text: maxbootR package provides fast consistent bootstrap methods block maxima, designed applications extreme value statistics. hood, performance-critical parts implemented C++ via Rcpp, enabling efficient computation even long time series. methods based first consistent bootstrap approach block maxima introduced Bücher & Staud (2024+): Bootstrapping Estimators based Block Maxima Method..

title: maxbootR
text: can install development version maxbootR GitHub : official CRAN repository R.
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("torbenstaud/maxbootR")

title: maxbootR
text: following example demonstrates extract sliding block maxima synthetic data. Time series block maxima simulated normal data
code: library(ggplot2) library(maxbootR) library(dplyr)  # Generate 100 years of daily observations set.seed(91) x <- rnorm(100 * 365)  # Extract sliding block maxima with 1-year window bms <- blockmax(xx = x, block_size = 365, type = "sb")  # Create time-indexed tibble for plotting df <- tibble(   day = seq.Date(from = as.Date("1900-01-01"), by = "1 day", length.out = length(bms)),   block_max = bms )  # Plot the block maxima time series ggplot(df, aes(x = day, y = block_max)) +   geom_line(color = "steelblue") +   labs(     title = "Sliding Block Maxima from Simulated Data",     x = "Year",     y = "Block Maximum"   )

title: maxbootR
text: now use maxbootr() function bootstrap 100-year return level synthetic data, comparing disjoint vs. sliding block bootstrap methods. sliding block method typically results narrower bootstrap distributions, reducing statistical uncertainty.
code: # Set block size (e.g., summer days) bsize <- 92  # Generate synthetic time series set.seed(1) y <- rnorm(100 * bsize)  # Bootstrap using disjoint blocks (+timing) system.time(   bst.db <- maxbootr(xx = y, est = "rl", block_size = bsize, B = 500,                       type ="db", annuity = 100) ) #>        User      System verstrichen  #>        0.72        0.00        0.78  # Bootstrap using sliding blocks (+timing) system.time(   bst.sb <- maxbootr(xx = y, est = "rl", block_size = bsize, B = 500,                       type = "sb", annuity = 100) ) #>        User      System verstrichen  #>        7.96        0.00        8.15  # Compare variance var(bst.sb) / var(bst.db) #>           [,1] #> [1,] 0.5502442

title: maxbootR
text: Histogram return level bootstrap replicates

title: maxbootR
text: full tutorial real-world case studies (finance & climate), check vignette included package.

title: maxbootR
text: implemented disjoint sliding block bootstrap methods grounded following foundational works: Gumbel, E. J. (1958). Statistics Extremes. Columbia University Press. Ferro, C. . T. & Segers, J. (2003). Inference clusters extreme values. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 65(2), 545–556. block bootstrap methodology based : Bücher, . & Staud, T. (2024+). Bootstrapping estimators based block maxima method. arXiv:2409.05529.

title: maxbootR
text: plan enhance maxbootR : Adding functionality computing (size-corrected) confidence intervals Providing built-plotting diagnostic functions Extending estimator support multivariate block maxima ideas contributions welcome — feel free open issue pull request GitHub!

what: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
title: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
text: Extracts block maxima univariate numeric vector matrix using disjoint, sliding, circular (k-dependent) block schemes.

title: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
code: blockmax(xx, block_size, type = "sb", k = 2)

title: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
text: xx numeric vector matrix. matrix input, row treated separate univariate series. block_size Positive integer. Size block maxima extraction. type Character. Type block maxima compute. One : "db" (disjoint blocks), "sb" (sliding blocks), "cb" (circular blocks k offsets). k Integer (used type = "cb"). Blocking parameter controls number blocks contained block blocks. Must integer 1 floor(length(xx) / block_size).

title: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
text: numeric vector (xx vector) matrix (xx matrix). entry contains block maxima computed according selected method.

title: Compute Block Maxima from a Time Series — blockmax
code: if (requireNamespace("maxbootR", quietly = TRUE)) {   set.seed(42)   x <- rnorm(100)    # Disjoint blocks of size 10   bm_db <- blockmax(xx = x, block_size = 10, type = "db")    # Sliding blocks of size 10   bm_sb <- blockmax(xx = x, block_size = 10, type = "sb")    # Circular blocks of size 10 with blocking parameter k = 2   bm_cb <- blockmax(xx = x, block_size = 10, type = "cb", k = 2) }

what: maxbootR: Efficient Bootstrap Methods for Block Maxima — maxbootR-package
title: maxbootR: Efficient Bootstrap Methods for Block Maxima — maxbootR-package
text: Implements state---art block bootstrap methods extreme value statistics based block maxima. Includes disjoint blocks, sliding blocks, generalized k-max transformation circular recombination. Fast C++ backends (via Rcpp) ensure scalability large time series. methods follow approach described paper ...

title: maxbootR: Efficient Bootstrap Methods for Block Maxima — maxbootR-package
text: Maintainer: Torben Staud torben.staud@gmail.com

what: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
title: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
text: Performs bootstrap resampling various block maxima estimators (mean, variance, GEV parameters, quantile, return level) using either disjoint sliding block methods.

title: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
code: maxbootr(   xx,   est,   block_size,   B = 1000,   type = "sb",   seed = 1,   p = NULL,   annuity = NULL )

title: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
text: xx numeric vector array containing univariate samples. multivariate cases, samples arranged rows. est string specifying estimator apply. Must one "mean", "var", "gev", "quantile", "rl". block_size Integer. Size block used block maxima extraction. B Integer. Number bootstrap replicates generate. type Type block bootstrapping: "db" disjoint blocks "sb" sliding blocks (internally approximated via circular blocks). seed Integer. Seed reproducibility. p Optional numeric value (0,1). Required est = "quantile". annuity Optional numeric value > 1. Required est = "rl" return level estimation.

title: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
text: numeric vector B rows scalar estimators. est = "gev", matrix B rows returned. row contains 3 estimated GEV parameters (location, scale, shape).

title: Bootstrap Estimation for Block Maxima — maxbootr
code: if (requireNamespace("maxbootR", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(maxbootR)   set.seed(123)   x <- rnorm(100)    # Bootstrap mean using sliding blocks   boot_mean <- maxbootr(x, est = "mean", block_size = 10, B = 20, type = "sb")    # Bootstrap variance using disjoint blocks   boot_var <- maxbootr(x, est = "var", block_size = 10, B = 20, type = "db")    # Bootstrap 95%-quantile of block maxima using sliding blocks   boot_q <- maxbootr(x, est = "quantile", block_size = 10, B = 20, type = "db", p = 0.95) }
